subject: RE: [junit] Can I create a dynamic JUnit ?  (in Cactus Framework)
msgSnippet: Cedric, TestSuite.addTest(Test) means add this test to this test suite TestSuite.addTestSuite(Class) means create the tests in Class and add them to this
messageBody:
Cedric,

TestSuite.addTest(Test) means "add this test to this test suite"
TestSuite.addTestSuite(Class) means "create the tests in Class and add them
to this test suite"

In the first example below you call addTestSuite(), so the constructor is
called once for each testXXX() method. In the second example the constructor
is called explicity, so it is only called once.

The OP described behavior that I don't understand. Once you create a
TestSuite, sending run() to it shouldn't create any more test objects.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

>
> > That's a little misleading and a little untrue. _If_ you run
> > JUnit on a class without a suite() method, or you have a
> > suite() method that calls TestSuite.addTestSuite(Class), then
> > _before any method is executed_, a fresh instance of the test
> > class is created for each test method in the class. However,
> > if you have a suite() method that calls
> > TestSuite.addTest(Test), which Donny did, then no such "automatic"
> > creation _should_ happen.
>
> Wow, you really had me there. I didn't believe it, so I
> tried it. And you
> are right.
>
> Run the following with JUnit:
>
> public class Test1 extends TestCase {
>
> public Test1() {
> System.out.println("Constructor invoked");
> }
>
> public void testA1() {
> System.out.println("test1");
> }
>
> public void testA2() {
> System.out.println("test2");
> }
> }
>
> and you will get
>
> Constructor invoked
> Constructor invoked
>
> Now, add a suite method:
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite= new TestSuite();
> suite.addTest(new Test1());
> return suite;
> }
>
> and you get
>
> Constructor invoked
>
> Now, what could possibly be the justification for this behavior?!?
